newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU's KEDO links could give huge trade boost.
newsitem.headline: EU's KEDO links could give huge trade boost.

text.p: European Union companies will be able to compete for millions of dollars of contracts in a North Korean power plant if the EU wins a place on the executive of the scheme's board, its director said on Wednesday.

Stephen Bosworth, executive director of the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organisation (KEDO), said the EU's proposed contribution totalling $100 million over five years to the scheme would make European companies eligible to bid for contracts "worth substantially more".
Bosworth is in Brussels to negotiate the European Union's entry to KEDO after EU foreign ministers earlier this month gave the European Commission a mandate to pursue membership.

KEDO was formed by the United States, Japan and South Korea to help North Korea develop its nuclear energy industry while at the same time ensuring its reactors are not diverted to non-energy activities.

In exchange for building two lightwater reactors by 2003 and supplying Pyongyang with 500,000 tonnes of heavy fuel oil a year until then, North Korea will dismantle two partially built heavy water reactors.
The KEDO founders make up the board's executive, but Bosworth told Reuters that the EU was likely to also win a place "in keeping with its financial and political status."
Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Chile, Indonesia and Finland are general members without a voice on the executive. -- David Fox, Brussels Newsroom +32 2 287 6832, Fax +32 2 230 7710
